item.title: Palabra del día en inglés: ‘decorum’
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 90 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Word of the Day: decorum
item.description: This word has appeared in 90 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Justice Dept. Sues Illinois Over Law Limiting Immigration Enforcement
item.description: The Justice Department said the law illegally regulates federal law enforcement by barring courthouse arrests and allowing residents to sue immigration agents.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gov. JB Pritzker of Illinois at a Chicago protest against the Trump administration in October.

item.description: Distributing water and food at a refugee camp in Siem Reap province in December.

item.title: Trump Needs to Rein in Netanyahu
item.description: President Trump should press Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to ease military pressure on Gaza, Lebanon and Syria for the sake of his own policy.
item.dc:creator: Nimrod Novik

media:content.media:credit: Jordan Bohannon

item.title: Trump Announces Construction of New Warships
item.description: President Trump announced on Monday the construction of new warships for the U.S. Navy he called a “golden fleet.” Navy officials said the vessels would notionally have the ability to launch hypersonic and nuclear-armed cruise missiles.
item.dc:creator: Nailah Morgan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: In giving the new class of ships his own name, Mr. Trump continued a self-aggrandizing streak of imprinting his brand on various aspects of the federal government.

item.title: The Pentagon and A.I. Giants Have a Weakness. Both Need China’s Batteries, Badly.
item.description: As warfare is reinvented in Ukraine, and Silicon Valley races to maintain its A.I. lead, China’s battery dominance is raising alarms far beyond the auto industry.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi, Brad Plumer and Harry Stevens
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: ¿Cuándo está listo el pavo? Todo lo que siempre quisiste saber (y no te atreviste a preguntar)
item.description: Te explicamos lo necesario para que el pavo quede en su punto: tiempos, técnicas y consejos clave.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Barrett Washburne.
media:content.media:description: The turkey will continue cooking as it rests.

item.title: After Bondi Massacre, a Moment of Unity. Then, Bitter Partisanship.
item.description: The political point scoring that has erupted after the terror attack last week is unusual in Australia, where leaders tend to unite after catastrophes.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Matthew Abbott

media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia and his wife leaving a memorial in Sydney on Sunday. Thousands had gathered on Bondi Beach a week after the attack there.

item.title: China Delays Plans for Mass Production of Self-Driving Cars After Accident
item.description: After years of planning for cars that would let drivers take their hands off the wheel and eyes off the road, China’s regulators have become more cautious.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.category: Guangzhou Xiaopeng Motors Technology Co Ltd (Xpeng Motors)

media:content.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A Changan Automobile assembly line in May. Changan is one of only two automakers approved to conduct limited testing of self-driving taxis.

item.title: Corrections: Dec. 23, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Dec. 23, 2025.

item.title: Quote of the Day: To New Middle Class, Nothing Seems Affordable
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 23, 2025.

item.title: Trump Administration Orders Nearly 30 U.S. Ambassadors to Leave Their Posts
item.description: A union representing career diplomats said such a mass recall had never happened in the history of the U.S. Foreign Service.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Trump administration did not give a reason for the recalls and has not publicly announced them.

item.title: White House Invitees Are Asked About Donations to Trump’s Ballroom
item.description: Senator Richard Blumenthal is requesting information from an architect hired to oversee the ballroom design and people invited to a donor dinner with the president.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump ordered the demolition the entire East Wing of the White House in October to make way for a 90,000-square-foot ballroom.

item.title: Trump Announces New ‘Trump Class’ of Warships
item.description: The president said development of the vessels would help maintain military superiority and improve the industrial base, but analysts suggested they were the wrong approach to current threats.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Eric Schmitt and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: In giving the new class of ships his own name, Mr. Trump continued a self-aggrandizing streak of imprinting his brand on various aspects of the federal government.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Dec. 23, 2025
item.description: Nathan Hale gets the corner office.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: May Britt, 91, Dies; Her Marriage to Sammy Davis Jr. Sparked Outrage
item.description: She was a white actress, he was a popular Black entertainer, and their relationship elicited racist reactions in 1960, worrying John F. Kennedy’s presidential campaign.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

media:content.media:credit: Hulton Archive/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Ms. Britt and Mr. Davis at their wedding in November 1960. It was reported that the event had been delayed from October at the request of John F. Kennedy’s presidential campaign to avoid negative attention before the election.

item.title: Turmoil at CBS News After Bari Weiss Pulls a ‘60 Minutes’ Segment
item.description: Several veteran correspondents questioned how Ms. Weiss, the new CBS News editor in chief, had handled the segment, after she defended her decision on a call with the newsroom.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum

media:content.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Manhattan studios of CBS News, whose editor in chief, Bari Weiss, spoke to the newsroom on Monday about a “60 Minutes” segment she had postponed. “I held that story because it was not ready,” she said.

item.title: After Power Outage, San Francisco Wonders: Can Waymo Taxis Handle a Big Earthquake?
item.description: City officials have called for a hearing investigating Waymo after the company’s self-driving taxis suffered widespread problems during a power outage.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla

item.title: Lawmaker Sues to Remove Trump’s Name From the Kennedy Center
item.description: Representative Joyce Beatty, Democrat of Ohio, argues that only Congress is authorized to rename the D.C. performing arts institution.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump’s name was added to the facade of the Kennedy Center last week after its board voted to rename it.

item.title: Trump Officials Sue to Loosen D.C.’s Gun Laws
item.description: The Justice Department challenged laws aimed at popular rifles including the AR-15 in the nation’s capital.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.category: US Federal Takeover of Metropolitan Police Dept (DC)

media:content.media:credit: Carlos Barria/Reuters
media:content.media:description: AR-15 rifles at a booth during the National Rifle Association annual convention in Dallas last year.

item.title: Lawmaker Sues Trump to Remove Name From Kennedy Center
item.description: Representative Joyce Beatty, Democrat of Ohio, sued President Trump on Monday seeking to force the removal of his name from the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

item.title: Mexican Medical Plane Crashes in Galveston Bay, Killing at Least 2
item.description: The plane was carrying four civilians and four crew members when it crashed into Galveston Bay, the Mexican Navy said. Two people on board survived and another was missing.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Livia Albeck-Ripka

media:content.media:credit: Jennifer Reynolds/The Galveston County Daily News, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Emergency personnel responding to a plane crash in heavy fog at Galveston Bay, in Galveston, Texas, on Monday.

item.title: Brown Faces Trump Investigation Over Security Issues Following Shooting
item.description: The Department of Education is looking at whether security at Brown University, including its surveillance system, was up to standard. Brown said it would conduct its own investigation.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault

media:content.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A memorial to the victims of the shooting at Brown University in Providence, R.I.

item.title: Young Turning Point Crowd Finds Infighting Distracting
item.description: “It’s creating division instead of building a movement that keeps everyone together.”

media:content.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Some of the event’s youngest attendees gathered around their phones.

item.title: F.D.A. Approves Wegovy Weight-Loss Pill
item.description: The agency greenlit an oral version of the obesity drug Wegovy.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

media:content.media:credit: Novo Nordisk
media:content.media:description: Wegovy weight loss pills have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration.

item.title: Judge Tells U.S. to Help Bring Back Deported Venezuelans or Allow Legal Challenges
item.description: The judge said the administration had to decide by Jan. 5 whether it wanted to “facilitate” the men’s return to the United States or let them contest their initial removals in the federal courts.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

media:content.media:credit: Fred Ramos for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The men were accused of belonging to the Venezuelan street gang Tren de Aragua and were deported to a notorious prison in El Salvador where many later claimed they had been tortured.

item.description: Over the weekend, Waymo’s self-driving cars came to a halt at intersections when an hourslong power outage in San Francisco knocked out traffic signals.
item.dc:creator: Chevaz Clarke

item.title: Trump Administration Declares Foreign-Made Drones a Security Threat
item.description: Americans won’t be able to buy new models from DJI, the Chinese maker of most of the world’s drones. But U.S. pilots can keep the drones they have.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman

media:content.media:credit: Christinne Muschi/Reuters
media:content.media:description: New models produced by DJI, the Chinese manufacturer that supplies much of the world’s drones, will no longer be sold in the United States.

item.title: Trump Administration Loosens Protections for Iconic Greater Sage Grouse
item.description: The government moves to make it easier to drill, mine and graze on 50 million acres of land in the West.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman

media:content.media:credit: Tom Reichner/Alamy
media:content.media:description: The greater sage grouse, a large chicken-like bird known for the males’ flamboyant courtship dance, is considered a key indicator of the health of an ecosystem that spans 11 Western states.

item.title: Trump Halts Offshore Wind Farms
item.description: Plus, Assad’s luxurious life in Moscow. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser

media:content.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Parts for Revolution Wind off Rhode Island, which was paused today.

item.title: Trump Administration Oil Tanker Seizures Are Meant to Force Maduro Out, Officials Say
item.description: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said the ship seizures were meant to force Venezuela’s president Nicolás Maduro from power.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Department of Homeland Security
media:content.media:description: On Saturday, the Coast Guard boarded the Centuries, a Panamanian-flagged tanker that had recently loaded Venezuelan crude oil, reportedly for a Chinese trader.

item.title: Nicki Minaj Praises Trump and Vance at Turning Point Event
item.description: The rapper Nicki Minaj, who previously criticized President Trump’s policies, praised him and Vice President JD Vance during a surprise appearance at a Turning Point USA event on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Chevaz Clarke

media:content.media:credit: Caylo Seals/Getty Images

item.title: ¿Es verdad que los geles energéticos ayudan a tu entrenamiento?
item.description: Los expertos nos dicen si deberías usarlos o no en tu entrenamiento.
item.dc:creator: Alex Hutchinson

media:content.media:credit: Justin J Wee para The New York Times

item.title: Ella Cook, Brown University Shooting Victim, Is Mourned at Funeral in Alabama
item.description: At a funeral in Alabama, the Brown University student was mourned as a gifted musician and protective sister who was committed to her faith.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Russell

media:content.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ella Cook was one of two students killed in a shooting this month at Brown University.

item.title: Record-Breaking Warm Temperatures Forecast for Christmas Across the U.S.
item.description: Unseasonably warm temperatures are expected across the United States this week, with many places hitting record highs and record-high lows.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar

media:content.media:credit: Mike Blake/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Unusual warmth is expected on Christmas and is connected to a broader weather pattern affecting the country.

item.title: El cambio de paradigma en favor de Trump ha muerto
item.description: Hace un año no dejábamos de oír que Trump ahora era “cool”. ¿Alguien lo dice ahora?
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein

media:content.media:credit: Evelyn Hockstein/Reuters

item.title: Palestinian Writer Raja Shehadeh: Israelis Live with a ‘Double Consciousness’
item.description: Raja Shehadeh, a Palestinian writer, lawyer and human rights activist, joined “The Interview” to talk about the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians and why he believes that peace remains possible.
item.dc:creator: The Interview

item.title: Writer Raja Shehadeh: ‘Zionism Has Made My Life Impossible’
item.description: The Palestinian writer and human rights activist Raja Shehadeh has been documenting the experience of living under Israeli occupation for decades. On “The Interview,” Shehadeh told host David Marchese that he believes that peace between the Israelis and Palestinians is possible, but for it to prevail, much would need to be fundamentally reconsidered.
item.dc:creator: The Interview

item.title: Why Palestinians and Israelis Don’t Know One Another
item.description: Raja Shehadeh, the Palestinian writer, lawyer and human rights activist, believes that peace between Israelis and Palestinians remains possible. On the latest edition of “The Interview,” Shehadeh talks to David Marchese about his life, his work and what he thinks needs to happen to get there.
item.dc:creator: The Interview

item.title: At Turning Point USA’s AmericaFest, Attendees Find Conservative Squabbling Distracting
item.description: “It’s creating division instead of building a movement that keeps everyone together.”
item.dc:creator: Nathan Taylor Pemberton and Jordan Gale

media:content.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The image of Charlie Kirk, the Turning Point USA founder who was assassinated in September, could be found across the Phoenix convention hall.

item.title: Two New Banksy Murals Appear in London
item.description: Two new London murals, widely attributed to the mysterious street artist, combine seasonal themes with what appears to be social commentary on rising child homelessness in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni

media:content.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A new mural by the artist Banksy appeared in Bayswater, in central London, on Monday.

item.title: Vince Zampella, Formative Designer of Call of Duty Games, Dies at 55
item.description: Mr. Zampella co-founded two game studios and also worked on the Medal of Honor, Titanfall and Battlefield franchises.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan

media:content.media:credit: Emily Berl for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Vince Zampella in 2014. He helped found Infinity Ward and Respawn Entertainment.

item.description: Why is it harder for men to have intimate friendships into adulthood?

item.description: Look up your location to find out.

item.title: What to Know About Norovirus: Symptoms, Transmission and More
item.description: The virus, sometimes called the stomach bug, is incredibly contagious. Here’s how to stay safe this season.
item.dc:creator: Simar Bajaj
item.category: State University of New York at Stony Brook

media:content.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Chris Rea, Grammy-Nominated Singer of ‘Driving Home for Christmas,’ Dies at 74
item.description: A blues-influenced singer and guitarist, he built a lasting career, particularly in Europe, with hits like “Driving Home for Christmas” and “Fool (If You Think It’s Over).”
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb

media:content.media:credit: Brill/ullstein bild via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Chris Rea performing in Cologne, Germany, in 1998. A virtuosic slide guitarist, he found fame and success, particularly in Europe, with a sound that blended blues, soul and soft rock.

item.title: Epstein Victims Ask Congress to Ensure Justice Dept. Releases All Files
item.description: More than a dozen women called for congressional hearings to ensure that the Justice Department is fully complying with the Epstein Files Transparency Act.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein

media:content.media:credit: Annabelle Gordon/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Jess Michaels at a news conference in November. She was among the women who signed the letter released Monday.

item.title: Restaurant Review: ChòpnBlok in Houston
item.description: In the age of boring bowls, Ope Amosu’s ChòpnBlok in Houston brings a welcome jolt of flavor, energy and joy.
item.dc:creator: Nyt Food

media:content.media:credit: Arturo Olmos for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mr. Amosu synthesizes flavors from across the Black diaspora in bowls like the Black Star.
